lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about someone's photo and find key details such as classroom objects and colours.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the short photo text aloud. Pause after each line and ask: “What can you see in the photo?” Students point to the object.
stretchStrategies: Play “Sound Train.” Draw a train with different letters (e.g. s, h, i, n) as train cars. Say a CVC word (e.g. “sit”) and students “ride” the sound train by hopping to each sound in order while saying the sounds aloud. Then try blending them together.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letters i, n, s, h to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Write “in,” “his,” “sit” on the board. Say slowly and have students repeat, clapping for each sound.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can name one thing that is the same and one thing that is different about classrooms in two countries
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show pictures of 2 different classrooms (or use SB). Ask: “What is the same? What is different?” Accept responses in L1 or English.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
